intro: Paepalanthus conduplicatus, commonly known as the double-leaved puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves that form a water-holding cup. The plant produces striking inflorescences with bright red or orange flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in high-altitude environments and is adapted to grow in rocky or sandy soils. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is often cultivated for ornamental purposes.
